newsitem.title: ARGENTINA: Argentine government delighted with postal offers.
newsitem.headline: Argentine government delighted with postal offers.

text.p: Argentina's government said Tuesday it was surprised at the high level of the offers received in its sale of a 30-year concession to run the state post office Encotesa.
"I am surprised; we did not expect the value of the offers made by the bidders," said Encotesa chief Arturo Puricelli, quoted by the state news agency Telam.
"We are aware that Encotesa deserves an important offer, but this one surpassed our expectations," he said. "We are selling a company for a value that other companies of bigger size were sold."
Bids for the concession were opened Monday but because the gap between the two top offers was less than five percent, the sale rules require new higher bids to be made in 72 hours.
The final bids will be opened at 1600 local time/1900 GMT on Thursday, Puricelli said. The five percent rule will not apply to this second round of bidding.
The top bid was a $51 million six-monthly fee offer by local firms Itron and Sideco, controlled by Grupo Macri, and Banco de Galicia, with the technical support of the British national post office.
The second highest bid of $48.5 million came from Argentine companies TAC and ROMAN, together with local businessman Samuel Liberman, owner of cable TV firm VCC, and Germany's state post office.
The winner will take over Encotesa on Sept 1.
